title: Ketosis and Chronic Diseases
content: The impact of ketosis on various chronic diseases as well as the latest research on the metabolic management of cancer. The numerous applications of hyperbaric oxygen therapy, provides insights into the application of ketosis on female health and performance. The potential role for vitamin C in cancer treatment. Glutamine targeting in cancer therapy—evidence that the mitochondria in cancer are damaged. Can a ketogenic diet lessen the toxicity of cancer therapies? The relationship between cancer and ketogenic diets. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT)—primer, protocols, and therapeutic uses. Non-cancer applications of HBOT. The inverse relationship between glucose and ketones. Is a ketogenic diet appropriate for type 1 diabetics? How ketosis may reduce the risk for Alzheimer’s disease and Parkinson’s disease. Ketosis for females—considerations, fertility, performance, and the latest research. Low-carb diets during pregnancy and postpartum. A high-protein diet to counteract common hormonal issues associated with the ketogenic diet. Nutritional tips for remaining metabolically flexible.

title: Metabolic Management of Cancer
content: Update on Dom’s Press-pulse therapeutic strategy for the metabolic management of cancer. The idea of using ketone metabolic therapy (or therapeutic ketosis) and other modalities to compromise tumor growth and proliferation. This weakens the tumor making it more susceptible to be killed by other modalities. Being in a state of therapeutic ketosis suppresses insulin signaling, which drives PI-3 kinase, lowers glucose availability to the tumor, elevates ketone bodies which can not be readily utilized by most cancers as a source of fuel. Ketones also impair antioxidant pathways that the tumors use to defend itself.

title: Vitamin C in Cancer Treatment
content: Potential role for vitamin C in cancer treatment. Most people think of vitamin C as an antioxidant but high concentrations of vitamin C can be a prooxidant–making it relevant in cancer treatment. Adding HBOT during radiation therapy kills cancer cells by 80 to 90% just through reactive oxygen species (ROS) generation because they are toxic tumor cells. The efficacy of radiation therapy is directly proportional to the pO2 of the tumor—so if you oxygenate the tumor and then radiate it there is a greater burst of intratumor ROS. Tumors tend to grow and outstrip their blood supply, so they’re hypoxic, making them resistant to radiation. So adding HBOT during radiation would dramatically sensitize it.

title: Mitochondrial Defects and Cancer
content: Defects in the mitochondrial electron transport chain can lead to the production of hydroxyl radical—a super reactive oxygen species—that can kill cancer cells very dramatically. This is driven by the Fenton reaction, which occurs when there is a lot of free iron available.

title: Vitamin C and Cancer
content: Dehydroascorbic acid—the oxidized form of vitamin C—uses the glucose transporter to get inside cells. If you elevate this form of vitamin C into millimolar concentrations in the blood using an IV, it functions as a glucose antagonist to the point where you may have hypoglycemic symptoms. This delivers a glucose antagonist that’s also dramatically increasing reactive oxygen species in cancer cells because tumors have a lot of free heme (iron).

title: Glutamine Targeting in Cancer Therapy
content: Literature suggests that tumor cells can be “addicted” to glutamine (i.e., mitochondrial substrate level phosphorylation with glutamine). This suggests that the mitochondria in cancer are damaged.

title: Ketogenic Diet and Cancer Therapy
content: Starting a ketogenic diet (especially calorie-restricted) “sets the stage” for cancer therapies to work—suppression of insulin signaling, decreasing glucose availability, limiting glutamine availability, lowering of many of the amino acids and associated anabolic signals that can drive tumor growth. It’s possible to “set the stage” nicely for an oxidative stress stimulus that could kill the cancer.

title: Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy (HBOT)
content: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) can be used for cancer research. Using info from the existing literature and preclinical animal models, they used the following protocol with the goal of killing a tumor—2.5 atmospheres of oxygen, 60-90 minutes, 3 times per week. HBOT has immune boosting effects, stimulates the mobilization (and maybe production) of stem cells, aids in wound healing, and may help athletes recover.

title: COVID-19 and HBOT
content: In regards to COVID-19, patients are becoming extremely desaturated. Hyperbaric oxygen therapy (HBOT) could potentially be used to treat COVID-19 patients.

title: COVID-19 and Oxygen Transfer
content: One theory suggests that COVID-19 causes hemoglobin to release oxygen. However, it is more likely that there’s a lack of O2 transfer in the lung due to inflammation in the tissues in the lung which are extremely damaged by COVID-19. This is contributing to the desaturation and not the COVID-19 desaturating the hemoglobin molecule by kicking oxygen off.

title: Hyperbaric Oxygen Therapy and COVID-19
content: There’s a potential role for hyperbaric oxygen to treat these disorders and restore oxygenation. Some reports came out of China showing that HBOT could reverse COVID-19 and save a patient’s life. However, there is a big risk in using HBOT on COVID-19 patients as it could be fueling a compromised system just through an increase in redox stress in the lung.

title: Non-cancer Applications of HBOT
content: Hyperbaric oxygen therapy can mobilize stem cells which, once in circulation, hone in on sites of injury and aid in repair and potentially regenerative processes. It can also stimulate the immune system. Some work demonstrates that hyperbaric oxygen increases gene expression of superoxide dismutase and catalase, and maybe glutathione too, through hyperbaric preconditioning. So it increases your endogenous antioxidant systems—which in theory could make you more resilient against subsequent oxidative challenges.

title: Ketogenic Diet and Type 1 Diabetes
content: A ketogenic diet can be used for those with type one diabetes. All 10 causes of death for humans are increased with type 1 diabetes, but they’re reduced when you use a low carb approach to managing type one diabetes. If you are a type 1 diabetic using insulin and you start a low carb ketogenic diet approach, the insulin dose needs to be adjusted because insulin requirements will be dramatically reduced and this needs to be done under very close supervision with an endocrinologist.

title: Ketosis and Neurodegenerative Diseases
content: Ketones function as an alternative fuel for the brain and this can mitigate symptoms of Alzheimer’s disease because a hallmark characteristic of most neurodegenerative diseases is brain glucose hypometabolism. Ketones could be functioning as an alternative fuel to restore brain energy metabolism in the face of glucose hypometabolism. Ketosis may also reduce the risk for Parkinson’s disease. Following a ketogenic diet (or supplemental ketosis) over time could prevent dopaminergic neurons from degenerating in the first place.

title: Ketosis and Female Health
content: One study found that 45% of the women in the study that were on a ketogenic diet experienced menstrual dysfunction (e.g., secondary amenorrhea). Secondary amenorrhea can also be caused by excess exercise, reduced energy intake, stress, and low body fat. A ketogenic diet may not be ideal for fertility as an infusion of exogenous ketones suppressed luteinizing hormone (LH), and the response was dependent upon an increase in catecholamines.

title: Ketogenic Diet and Fertility
content: Ketones may be a signal to the body and the brain that it may not be the best time for child rearing—because if you have low resources (e.g., fasted) you’re going to be in a state of ketosis. However, for females that have metabolic syndrome and insulin resistant (e.g., polycystic ovary syndrome, or PCOS), the ketogenic diet can restore their fertility and restore their hormonal balance. A clinical ketogenic diet (high fat, low carb) should be approached cautiously, whereas a low carb, moderate-to-high protein diet may be a better choice for females that are going to try this approach to reduce carbohydrates gradually.

title: Ketogenic Diet and Female Health
content: From the epilepsy literature, we do see some sort of hormonal/fertility issues when girls who have epilepsy are using the ketogenic diet and they go through puberty, that can influence their ketone levels. Two studies, (Vargas-Molina et al., 2020 and Gregory et al., 2017), looked at the ketogenic diet for lean body mass and performance in women—The observation was that women on a low carb ketogenic diet could maintain lean body mass and increase performance.

title: Low-carb Diets during Pregnancy and Postpartum
content: Considerations for women considering low-carb and/or keto diets during pregnancy and postpartum. Be cautious using a purely ketogenic diet during pregnancy. Keto diets dramatically suppress insulin (a growth hormone), and can have great health consequences. However, during pregnancy you want to grow and do not want to impair growth of the developing fetus. In the case of a pregnant woman is obese or a type 2 diabetic, low-carb approach can be very powerful approach.

title: High-protein Diet for Women with Hormonal Issues
content: A lot of the issues and side effects that women are experiencing are probably from—Calorie restriction, Overexercising, And suppression of insulin signaling from calorie restriction plus carbohydrate restriction. The insulin suppression impact women more than men in terms of maintaining a hormone balance (especially with the sex hormones). Periodically increasing protein into your diet may be beneficial for women to avoid some of the potential counterregulatory hormonal effects that can occur through insulin suppression associated with the ketogenic diet.

title: Nutritional Tips for Remaining Metabolically Flexible
content: “I think it’s really important to pulse insulin occasionally in and around training. And that definitely facilitates repair of tissues, recovery.” If you’re using a diet therapeutically, it’s important to maintain insulin suppression and low blood glucose and ketones. For a normal, healthy person using the ketogenic diet as a lifestyle—For someone doing physical activity of exercise, you need to enhance recovery at times. Spiking insulin into the moderate range a few times a week can really be beneficial to assist in recovery, but to also keep that energetic pathway open.

title: Anti-catabolic Effects of Ketones and Cancer Cachexia
content: Cancer cachexia is a form of weight loss, specifically muscle, associated with cancer and is a big issue. The study showed that the muscle-sparing effects of ketones were pretty remarkable in multiple model systems. When people reach the point where they can’t move around and exercise (due to cancer cachexia), they rapidly decline and succumb to the tumor burden much quicker. And the anti-catabolic effects of ketones may be able to mitigate.

title: Nutritional Interventions for Cancer Patients
content: We need engineered foods for cancer patients. Carbohydrate restricted, Moderate in protein to supply just enough protein to meet the needs of the cancer patient. Plus we need a whole ingredient list of natural additives that have anti-cancer properties, a few examples being—EGCG, Turmeric, DHEA in certain situations, Omega-3 fatty acids can also have an anticatabolic anti-cancer cachexia effect.
